Before posting a thread, please check our catalog to ensure that a thread about the same topic does not already exist.

>And Europe did invent a crossbow during the Greek era, but it never saw mass usage because greeks considered ranged weapons to be a weapon of cowards lol.

This

The Greeks and the Romans regarded heroic combat, fighting man to man, as the highest military ideal. They still used bows and other ranged weaponry, but regarded range warfare as a less desirable form of combat. Hence, why military development in Europe was an odd-duck compared to the type of range-centric warfare that was more common in the Eurasian continent. With European armor and weaponry focusing on proficiency in melee combat as opposed to proficiency in range combat.

>>57025938
I'm not sure about ancient times, as it's not my main focus of interest but crossbows were extremely prolific during the high and late medieval times. There are inventory lists of small castles that would be manned by just a couple dozen men at best containing hundreds of crossbows and tens of thousands of bolts.
You see crossbows being used with great effect by many European armies of the time. From some notable examples in history, Richard 1st of England, more commonly known as Richard The Lionheart was a great proponent of usage of crossbows. During the battle of Arsuf Muslim sources explicitly state that where Christians were nearly impervious to their composite bows, continuing fighting with arrows sticking out of their backs, where the crossbows killed men and horses on the spot.
Richard also died to a crossbow bolt, but before he died from his wounds he reportedly pardoned the shooter because he thought it was a nice shot.
During later period in Eastern Europe, particularly 15th century Poland and Bohemia, crossbows were used very commonly and with great effect even when first firearms started to enter the field.
During the 1410 battle at Grunwald Poles used mounted crossbowmen in conjunction with heavy cavalry, having the mounted crossbowmen ride behind the knights on charges and firing crossbows over their heads to make sure the Teutonic Order troops were unable to properly brace against an incoming charge.

Economics and logistics, mostly. Torsion engines were expensive to build and maintain, difficult to transport, and the best torsion batteries (made from horsehair) did *not* like to get wet, or even damp.

Pre-gunpowder field artillery just really wasn't a thing (yes, there were exceptions, but they were just that--exceptions). Artillery was something you built on-site during a siege. It's kind of a pity, because looking back on it, we are well aware today of the massive impact that field artillery has had on decisive battles in recent centuries. For the most part, however, trying to apply our modern preconceptions onto ancient battlefields just doesn't quite work out. Real history doesn't match up with Conan, much less D&D.

To follow up on this point, most castles were not made purely from stone. >ANKARA — A South Korean manufacturer, SNT Dynamics, said this week it will supply transmissions for the engines that will power the Altay, Turkey’s first indigenous tank.

>The subsidiary of SNT Holding announced it has signed a deal with BMC, a Turkish-Qatari partnership that builds the Altay, to supply the EST15K, a 1,500-horsepower automatic transmission. The South Korean company said the export deal includes $74.9 million of supply until 2027 and has an option for further sourcing priced at $141 million between 2028 and 2030.

>SNT said the deal was signed after field tests and assessment, including an endurance driving test last year.

>“It is a valuable achievement through a harsh test evaluation, such as completing a night-based driving of about 200 kilometers (124.27 miles) a day even in the local rough terrain and environment,” the company said.

>The first phase of Altay tanks will be equipped with a Korean power group consisting of a Hyundai Doosan production DV27K diesel engine and SNT Dynamics production EST15K gearbox.

>BMC expects to deliver the first two tanks to the Turkish government in May 2023. Field tests are expected to continue until 2025, both by the Turkish Armed Forces and by contractors.

>Mehmet Karaaslan, general manager of the company, said BMC is slated to turn over eight units a month for an initial batch of 100 units.

>BMC won the multibillion-dollar Altay contract in 2018. That contract provides for a first lot of 250 tanks, life-cycle logistical support and the establishment and operation by the contractor of a tank systems technology center.

posts.name: Burt
posts.com:
I hope somebody here snaps one or both of these up, man these are cool. Both quite rare guns though only a little weird.

The Sirkis is an early version of what would later be called the Sardius SD9 whose only virtue is you've probably never heard of it lol. The Tressitu is a South African (TZ99) copy of the Israeli copy (Golan) of the Yugoslavian copy (CZ99) of the P226/P88. Mechanically not super interesting as these lack the CZ99's "3 round hand poke indicator" but this one is factory hard chromed which is very rare. I had been looking for one of these for about 10 years with zero results until I stumbled on to a CZ99 to fill this niche.

https://handgunsoftheworld.com/product/sirkis-industries-sirkis-sd9-9mm-with-case/

https://handgunsoftheworld.com/product/tressitu-mitchell-double-action-9mm-with-case/

He's also got a Mamba, a CZ 100, a Detonics Pocket 9, an FMK 9C1 Bill of Rights Edition and a Dardick 1500 (!) for sale but I think they're all way overpriced.

This may be giving the Russians too much credit
My personal opinion is there will be no attack from the north, I think the initial shit show of the invasion and ass beating they received is something they know they would not like to repeat across that terrain again. Any Russian units in Belarus that aren't being trained are just to try and force Ukraine to hold forces nearby in reserve.
There will likely be attacks from the south towards zaporizhzhia but I personally think that any offensive here is again just to fix forces in the region, they'll see if they can peel more territory away to reinforce their land bridge to crimea.

The main focus will be the entire donetsk and luhansk oblasts. They'll concentrate everything they have on this goal. If the russians are able to take these two oblasts and preserve the land bridge they will attempt negotiations to end the war and come away with what they could spin as a victory. Will this work? Most likely not. I don't believe Ukraine will accept this and will continue fighting.

If the Russians do attempt an offensive in the next weeks (I find this unlikely but still possible) my opinion is it's because time isn't on their side. Support for ukraine is ramping up and they would be foolish to gamble on that support waning anymore. Redlines for weapon systems continue being crossed (even if they are late like with MBTs) so they must have reasonably assumed that aircraft and ballistic missiles aren't far off. There's also the issue of GLSDB's which if delivered in the next few months will further strain the already difficult logistics situation.

There is some logic to attacking early, circumventing the advantages that certain weapons would provide ukraine, namely imo GLSDBs and potentially ATACMs which would hit so many command centers and supplies/logistical nodes that large scale operations may grind to a halt and become untenable.

What is your opinion on banning the us of leaded ammo and plastic shotcups/wads for hunting and only for hunting?

https://www.mlive.com/news/2023/02/michigan-bald-eagles-are-dying-of-lead-poisoning-the-reason-may-surprise-you.html

It doesn't take much lead to sicken or kill a bald eagle, and wildlife rehabilitators say the birds are being poisoned by accidentally ingesting bullets while scavenging carcasses from animals killed by hunters using lead ammunition, reported MLive.

“If you’ve ever seen an eagle that has been poisoned, it’s something you’ll never forget,” said John Buchweitz, nutrition and toxicology section chief at Michigan State University Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory. “The animal may go blind. They can develop tremors. They can lose their ability to fly. It’s a sad statement on the truly adverse effects of a chemical, like lead, on an animal.”

America's national symbol were removed from the endangered species list after a then-controversial federal ban on the pesticide DDT nearly killed off the species, which had dwindled to just 417 nesting pairs in 1963 to more than 300,000 bald eagles currently living in the wild, and conservationists are now sounding the alarm on hunting or fishing with lead-based products.

“We’re going to have to use every available resource to get this out,” said James Manley, executive director of Skegemog Raptor Center. “There’s a lot of steps I think we’re going to have to go through to get enough people on our side where it’s like, okay, let’s quit putting a known toxin into the environment.”

A study published last year found nearly half of bald and golden eagles nationwide tested positive for chronic lead poisoning, and it's the third leading cause of death for the species in Michigan, and research shows the main source is lead ammunition from wild game carcasses and the entrails hunters leave behind from cleaning game in the field.

i will tell you because i design pipe systems for a living
lead doesn’t get into the water if you have water which scales the pipes
scaling deposits a thin layer of minerals on the pipe, meaning the water doesn’t touch lead
but you can have water sources which do not scale, and therefore the lead leaches
this has famously been a problem in america

The reason was that it was being ingested by stupid waterfowl who "sweep" the bottom of the pond with their beaks as they float to get food (see: duck with its head underwater and ass in the air) and it gets ground up in their gizzards. posts.name: Anonymous

>>57027592
Just cranking the pressure has multiple levels of diminishing returns, along with absolutely mulching the chamber of the gun. The 140mm's higher surface area allows for more thrust for the same pressure. Also a major limiting factor for darts these days is penetrator length, stuff like M829A3 has the dart stretch all the way back to the primer inside the case. So the larger case of the 140mm allows for more room.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have finally decided to order a RMR for my pistol. (I have no experience with pistol red dots) It is my only pistol, and I have had it for a little over a year and have been shooting it weekly. I love it but my only complaint is the sights are too large for precise shots at slightly longer distances. The sights are fine for up close fast acquisition, but I feel like this is a very justified upgrade.

If it was just a plinking toy I wouldn't bother, but I am mounting the dot on my main carry piece.

I have heard people arguing against an absolute cowitness.

I am leaning towards a lower 1/3 because it stays out of the way of your primary sight (the dot), but allows you to retain a acceptable degree of accuracy if the dot fails for whatever reason (like if you are retarded and forget to change the battery, or you come in contact with a bright ass light that drowns out the dot)

What is /k/'s experience with either of these methods? Is there anything else I should know about red dots and pistol irons in this context?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The best part of absolute cowitness is it doesnt change your hold from guns without a red dot . Any gun with or without a dot will be held the same way and if the dot goes out you wont have to alter how high you hold the gun. It seems like its a minor thing but if you actually practice and use the gun like you should it could throw you off a bit. Muscle memory is great but it can also be a real bitch.

In reality for 99% of people that dont practice like its their job it doesnt matter. Having some form of cowitness is better than none though just incase the dot dies when you actually need it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57035637
my stock sights are low enough on the gun that when I mount my RMR they will become useless. I will have to get higher "suppressor height" or similar sights to actually be able to use them.

Would using higher sights change your point of aim/point of impact? If I understand the concept correctly I think it would, but I am not sure how drastic an effect it would have

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57035669

Its a negligible difference. If you raise the sights a half inch or whatever it just changes the point of aim point of impact difference by the same amount. Its only a real issue if you are one of those competitive accuracy shooters and have to mess with shooting at range a bunch cause the difference means the zeroing can change a lot more at range than normal but most of the time its not even noticeable.

All i will say is that if its going to be a main CC gun spring for the sights to have some form of cowitness. You dont want to draw the gun when you absolutely need it and find out the dot has a dead battery or broke somehow. If you carry something you want to be able to rely on it 120% of the time. Failure is not an option.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

For pistols you 100% want lower 1/3rd.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57016666
Take a break man, get in a comfortable place, when you're ready there will be a lot of information available for you to search.
For now if you have to move them
>pay the most attention to where the barrel is pointed and ensure no one is in it's path even between walls. Pointed down at the ground when walking is generally best but if that's not an option floor level flat or straight up leaned against a wall works. In a case is great because it can help protect the trigger from foreign objects.
>keep your finger outside the "trigger gaurd", don't rest your finger on the trigger, and make sure theyre not positioned so that some object can get into the trigger gaurd and touch the trigger.
If you can be mindful of those two things you won't get you or anyone else hurt.
If you're wanting to baby them
>keep in mind that despite them being metal the finish often scratches easily and to be gentle with them. Throwing them in a pile is going to damage the metal and wood stock.
>gun oil, there's thousands of different brands can be wiped with a paper towel across all the metal to prevent rust. Just a thin film of it don't get it really wet. Barrel cleaner is different and you can save that for later.
When you're ready to unload I'd watch YouTube videos of the same or different similar guns being operated. To get an idea of what you're working with. For example, to swing out a cylinder on a colt revolver a sliding button goes the opposite direction of a smith and wesson but both swing out to the left while other revolvers might have a fixed cylinder position or even be break open.
>If you post your gun anywhere don't let the serial number show in the photo. The make, model, chambering is good to know though. The text for make and model is frequently on the action while the clambering is often on the barrel.
>if you know someone good with guns who won't steal from you they can help. Guns are expensive and can walk off easy.

When you cock things, look inside the action where it opens and if you see the start of the barrel (where the shell would be driven into if it was loaded) is empty you should be good. >>57016666
We can walk you through some pointers.
The basics are
>Assume every gun is loaded even when you think it isn't. Check it every time you pick one up to be sure.
>Never let the muzzle cover anything you aren't willing to destroy. Particularly other people.
>Keep your finger away from the trigger unless you are ready to fire.
>If you are shooting at something, be aware of it and what is around/behind it.

Muzzle and trigger discipline take a lot of getting used to. You'll slip a few times if you're new but the best thing about the basic 4 rules is you'd have to fuck them all up at the same time to have a serious accident where somebody gets hurt.

With that said.
>>57018385
>38 Snub nose
That's broadly what it is, in the sense that a Honda Accord is a midsize sedan. It appears to be a Smith and Wesson, although I'm not certain of the exact model. With the cable lock through the frame the cylinder is not engaged so it's safe to handle. Look into the cylinder and it should be empty. I see there's a speed loader with some ammo in the box.
>>57018534
It's a legitimate point. Actual markings engraved on the guns will tell us a lot more than a grainy dark picture will, for instance what type of bullets any given gun shoots.

That one is a Winchester 1200 or 1300.
To check it, (remember KEEP YOU FINGER AWAY FROM THE TRIGGER) there is a little square switch near the trigger called the bolt release (not the round one that's red and goes side to side, that's a safety). If you push the bolt release in, the slide (which is the pump up front) will be able to move. Once unlocked you pump it back and if there is a shell in the chamber ready to fire it will be kicked out of the gun. There could be more in the tube, but holding the bolt release in and pumping it a bunch of times will empty them all out.

If you pump it back and nothing comes out cycle it a few times anyway

Probably a wrist GPS or a hardened smartphone. A watch for its own sake in this day and age (thats to say: a dedicated timepiece as opposed to a multifunctional tool) is indulgent bordering on jewelry. I remember in scouts back in ~2007 they were teaching us about how to find north with the hands of an analog watch in relation to the sun, and while a novel idea it felt redundant because the only kids present who wore watches had digital casio ones. That was pre-smartphone, so I assume these days even fewer people wear them. Thats why its weird to hear a lot of guys these days bragging about buying a rolex, its in the same league as spending 500 bucks on a bolo tie or getting a hand tailored zoot suit; or some other anachronism.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57035077
>worked hard
As a french I can tell you this is a no brainer, so no brainer they 100%y came up with it by accident and it saved us the trouble of adding a nickname (like véhicule blindé multirôle (VBMR) « Griffon » )
And no "Caesar" isn't some taboo word here.

You probably took too much from "Leclerc" tank (named in his honor yes and not an acronym at all)

Our other tank have bland acronym:
>AMX10-RC
AMX stand for: Atelier de issy-les-MoulinauX
(place it was built at, we skip the issy yes)
RC = Roue Canon
(wheel + canon)

If you see
>NG
>Nouvelle Generation
New Generation

Some other french military acronym worth mentioning
>CaRaPACE
>Camion Ravitailleur Pétrolier de l’Avant à Capacité Étendue
carapace = animal shell
literally "extended range front line refueling truck"

>SOUVIM
>système d’ouverture d’itinéraire miné
Literally "system to clear a road with land mine"

>FAMAS
>Fusil D'Assaut De La Manufacture D'Armes De Saint-Etienne
Literally "rifle of ... industry it came from"

>PA-MAS est l'acronyme de Pistolet Automatique de la Manufacture d'Armes de Saint-Étienne
Same for pistol

>FÉLIN (Fantassin à Équipement et Liaisons Intégrés, Integrated Infantryman Equipment and Communications) is the name for the French infantry combat system

>nEUROn drone prototype
literally neuron + Euro
I skip all the other Euro

>MAGIC missile
>Missile Auto-Guidé Interception et Combat

>MICA missile
>Missile d’Interception, de Combat et d’Auto-défense

>MILAN
>Missile d'Infanterie Léger Antichar (French for "Lightweight Infantry Anti-tank Missile")

>Radio CONTACT (Communications numérisées tactiques et de théâtre)
>Système ATLAS (Automatisation des tirs et liaisons de l'artillerie sol/sol)
>Radar SPARTIATE (système polyvalent d’atterrissage de recueil de télécommunication et d’identification de l’altitude)
>Radar COBRA (radar de contrebatterie)

posts.sub: US Congress to assess challenges of AUKUS implementatiom
posts.com:
a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense shall seek to enter into an agreement with a federally funded research and development center for the conduct of an independent assessment of resourcing, policy, and process challenges to implementing the partnership among Australia, the United Kingdom, and United States (commonly known as the ‘‘AUKUS partnership’’) announced on September 21, 2021.

(b) MATTERS TO BE CONSIDERED.—In conducting the assessment required by subsection (a), the federally funded research and development center shall consider the following with respect to each of Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States:
(1) Potential resourcing and personnel shortfalls.
(2) Information sharing, including foreign disclosure policy and processes.
(3) Statutory, regulatory, and other policies and processes.
(4) Intellectual property, including patents.
(5) Export controls, including technology transfer and protection.
(6) Security protocols and practices, including personnel, operational, physical, facility, cybersecurity, counterintelligence, marking and classifying information, and handling and transmission of classified material.
(7) Industrial base implications specifically including options to expand the United States submarine and nuclear power industrial base to meet United States and Australia requirements.
(8) Alternatives that would significantly accelerate Australia’s national security, including—
(A) interim submarine options to include leasing or conveyance of legacy United States submarines for Australia’s use; or
(B) the conveyance of B-21 bombers.
(9) Any other matter the Secretary considers appropriate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57013703
If you're on that side of the line, it's intermediate. If you're on this side of the line, it's full power. There are standards, and if the majority of them are reached, then it is full power. If they aren't, then it isn't. This isn't really difficult. 7.4mm minimum projectile width, intended for use beyond 300m (on targets human sized or larger), atleast a max effective range of 800m (always debatable), and a case length of 50mm or longer. The very first example wikipedia gives is 6.5x55mm Swedish, showing that the term can be flexible, but it must meet all the other requirements to be acceptable.
Sort of like the Garand. It's a battle rifle even though it has an internal mag, because it's fed via enbloc clips, and meets all other requirements of the Battle Rifle definition.
We can debate all day long whether or not a cartridge is full power or intermediate, but raw data is the deciding factor. Perhaps a new retronym is needed for bullets between intermediate and full power

>>57016416
Sorry, I thought you were quizzing us. I think the NRCH makes more sense, but the RCH should be somewhat easier to clear malfunctions on. The way the forward assist works on the NRCH is a bit weird. It's not like an FAL (or XCR that copied the FAL) where you push it it to engage the bolt, but needs the CH to be pulled back until it engages with the bolt, then disengages again once its all the way forward. But engaging it takes some force, so necessarily means pulling the bolt back, you can't JUST force it forward unless its on the first round loaded. If it does need help on the first round you can just tap it closed like an RCH since it's engaged until it's all the way forward.
But in exchange for making one method of malfunction clearing mildly more annoying you have a CH that won't hit you or shit you lean the gun against, and you can have one on both sides if wanted.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57014568
Not the anon, but are you trying to argue that FN’s 6.5x43 is intermediate because it (externally) is similar to 6.5 grendel or 6mm ARC? I don’t know if the other anon’s claims that the 6.5x43 runs at high pressure has been confirmed, but I have the same suspicions that it’s a giga pressure round. Increasing the pressure of a cartridge has an effect similar (almost the same as) to increasing the power charge by a proportional amount. If you doubled the pressure of a 5.56, you’d achieve the performance of what a 308 necked to .224 could do. Play around with internal ballistics computers and you’ll see what I’m talking about. 2 cartridges, even if identical externally, could be 2 different beasts just by virtue of pressure differences.

How you’d characterize such a round, I’m not sure, and maybe it’s a pointless exercise.. we don’t really have a concrete, autistic definition of “intermediate cartridge”. There isn’t a hard foot pound limit, or action length limit, or recoil energy limit, or case head size limit.

Took the SCAR 20 out for the first time today. posts.com:
>>57034805
I wouldn't/didn't get one. Had every opportunity back when they were cheap, and thought Galils were cool. For some reason Galils and FALs were all the rage in early 2000s up until 2010 or so. There really weren't that many known guns, and the online community didn't know shit. Options were more limited anyway, but I decided against one. First of all the Golani is Century trash. Not by any means one of their acceptable projects either. The Galil itself is heavier than an AK with no real gain. Its parts are far less common, and the upturned charging handle negates the use of optics, if there even is a mounting system present. I don't think the Galil has ever had optic mounting options.

What everyone did back then instead was get a Saiga and put Tapco Galil furniture on it. It's obvious that just the stocks, grips, and handguards on it are sexy. Then you maintain the lighter weight and commonality of the AK. The best not-an-AK by far is the VZ58. Lighter, more accurate, and has better features than any AK, Galil, Valmet, etc. There is no better option if you're looking for a Cold War design, all steel, 7.62x39 or 5.56 shooter. You can get a Galil if you really think it looks that cool and must have it, but in terms of practicality and performance it's shit compared to a common AK or VZ.

>rechambered for 308 cetme
No it wasn't.
7.62 CETME isn't even a lower pressure cartridge, it's a lower recoiling cartridge, but it has the same pressure. The CETME cartridge used a light aluminum bullet pushed out with basically pistol powder. It was only made for the early CETME rifles to fire at full auto, not for bolt action rifles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56948420
>What's the clasp mean?
A gloved finger jammed into the triggerguard tended to depress the catch and dump the magazine floorplate and magazine contents. Russians first put a sheet metal clasp around the lever, then switched to grinding the raised thumbpiece of the lever off from the inside of the triggerguard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: This SMLE Mk.I*** is only rare on a curve compared to the glut of Mk.III*. A late 1911 manufacture date means this rifle was likely intended for the Royal Navy, who were still on the Mk.I* and had not yet adopted the Mk.III. It might have gone to the British Army during WW1; there's a possible unit marking on the buttstock and it was updated for Mk.VII ball (hence the additional **). In 1922 this rifle was sent to the newly formed Irish National Army (the pro-Treaty faction of the IRA) and so it saw service in the tail end of the Irish Civil War. These Irish rifles were sold as surplus to INTERARMS in 1960 and imported into the United States.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56982387
IIRC the "crossed rifles" on Carcanos is not an indicator of exceptional accuracy. It means that specific rifle was tested for accuracy and it met the minimum accuracy standards. All rifles were proof tested but not all rifles were accuracy tested because of time/budget constraints. If the selected rifle failed the accuracy test it meant there was a potential production problem and that batch of rifles made since the last recorded successful accuracy test had to be examined more carefully.

posts.com: Lads I can get a swiss 1889 for cheap, and I'm gonna start reloading soon. How hard is it to trim and load for the G90 type loads?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57011785
With my chamber I did not need to trim at all. These rifles were cut with a tremendous throat to accommodate the paper patched bullet so it’ll just depend on your example. Trimming is easy anyway. Loading GP90 is annoying as it’s small diameter paper patched. Loading the final iteration, the GP90/06/23 (non corrosive primer in 1906 and metallic jacketed bullet in 1923) is far easier. Use any 180-200gr .308 seated as far out as it’ll go and drop your GP11/7.5x55 load data by about 30% depending on the powder. They can be extremely accurate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57011785
>>57012593
I should add that I found flat based bullets to shoot much better, the long tapered throat doesn’t allow boat tails to bump up fully or evenly. I think it was sierra flat based round nosed 180s that shot best for me.

>>57011785
Reloading for the 89 chamber isn't hard. I just use regular 7.5x55 brass, the throat is generous enough you probably won't need to trim, unless you're loading paper patched bullets. Might just look a bit weird after firing, I trimmed mine down to 55mm just for good measure.
33.5g of imr4895 and a hornady 180g rnsp gets me 1moa accuracy out of my 89/96.
220g hornady rnsp are currently available and should be perfect.
Make sure to anneal your brass as your neck will expand a shit ton after firing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Previous >>56962567
Old Cover New Thread
Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

>>57033162
Consider a storage locker (an appropriate one for guns) that isn't in your apartment. The outside chance of about 0.0001% that someone is going to break into your apartment while you are there is something that you can skip for "only a few years."

If you REALLY feel like you just HAVE to have a gun with you in your apartment, store all your quality shit somewhere and keep a cheap, sacrificial shooter "just in case." If you shoot it, you're going to lose it (plus face whatever charges). better to lose something you don't care about instead of your entire collection plus all the ammo and accessories.

Keep the bare minimum for home defense, and make it one that won't kill or injure or even slightly endanger your apartment neighbors through the walls. Minimum ammo, minimum essential accessories. Should you ever get caught (such as having to use it), you can defend yourself in court a LOT better even if you're breaking local ordinances. You can demonstrate critical need for self defense instead of sitting in front of the judge while the prosecution lays out the armory of a psychopath and proves you spent your life looking for an excuse to experience the thrill of murdering a human being.

If you can't take this seriously, you need to give up your guns. You're not stable enough to be in possession of any. If you can't figure out how to conceal one solid shooter and a half box of ammo in your apartment on your own, you're not taking this seriously. Nobody here knows anything about the apartment you live in, so nobody is going to be able to answer your question.

(You) are welcome.

>>57032700
They're literal range toys that briefly had a use in an era when single-shot pistols or shitty Belgian .32s were the only alternative.
>They seem cheap, very concealable, and capable of handling some pretty big boolits.
The thing that picture doesn't show you is how fucking big the Derringer actually is. That medallion on the grip? It's the size of a quarter. Large-bore ones are about the same size as a Ruger LCP and much less capable. They also REALLY suck to shoot in larger calibers. Birds-head grips + skinny spur hammer + three-finger grip means that unless you're clamping it like your mom grips cock it's gonna tear the shit out of your hand after a couple of shots in anything heavier than a pocket revolver caliber. I've seen the exact same .44 Mag derringer go through the local gun shop's used counter like clockwork. Every couple-three months for the last five years some idiot buys it, puts five rounds through it, and takes it back to the store.

If you want a self-defense gun, get a pocket revolver or a subcompact. It'll cost the same, be vastly more effective, and be just as concealable if not more so. If you want a range toy, by all means get one. Preferably in a silly caliber that's fun to reload.

>>57026192
Was cop, yes we did shit like this. SWAT mainly. But I did a few night time building clearing exercises. We'd use whatever abandoned buildings we could coordinate with the owner to use. Our main one was an abandoned warehouse where we did simround stuff. The type of shit in the webm is more high profile, our SWAT would do shit like that but involving our Bear and Bearcat, never helos. This is probably military, they go all out and yes they can coordinate with a building owner too. The only military training I ever saw was a SERE simulation. SERE includes a live practice where they get fake kidnapped out of their beds, handcuffed or tied, put in a van, driven off base somewhere, then they have to escape and evade their way back. We were told to arrest them if we saw them in their white jumpsuits. They're supposed to straight up steal clothes and shit to blend in or use the woods to get back. I didn't find any of them, would've been illegal to just arrest them without probable cause anyway unless it's consensual training. I took a lockpicking and restraint defeating course with the air force and the same guys that would later take part in that training were there, but we didn't coordinate that part so if they actually resisted in a non-training environment it would be a mess.

>wrong, javelins only perfectly hit the top of the tank 100% of the time

No it doesnt, Javelin has a forward firing shaped charge, it comes in at an angle, not from 90 degrees straight down. It means that it can blast the back of the turret or hit the top of the engine deck depending on engagement geometry. Javelin should be an ideal target for an APS because of the high altitude dive down attack.

Swedish BILL 1 and 2 have a shaped charge that fires forward and downward at 45 degrees as the missile passes over the tank like a regular AT missile. The warhead in NLAW is the same as in BILL 2. The Javelin is the american military industrial complex's last hurrah, it is now too corrupt and dysfunctional to do anything more than inventing improved TOWs. posts.com: I know this isn’t related to enlistment, but Has anybody here taken the ASTB? I’m taking it next week and I’m very nervous. My naval science instructor told me people recommend going in blind the first time, only recently have I realized that he’s absolutely HAD me and this is a really dumb idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57032974
Section 1: MST (Math Skills Test): Nothing you probably haven’t seen before in high-school but, it’s definitely worth brushing up on. You’re going to see some basic arithmetic, geometry, algebra, angles, and perimeter, along with the occasional time and distance word problem and potentially some basic probability.

Section 2: RCT (Reading Comprehension Test): Again, really straightforward stuff. You read a passage of text and are given options of sentences only one of which is totally true based on the text given above. Most will seem true but, only one can actually be derived from the provided passage.

Section 3: MCT (Mechanical Comprehension Test): The questions in this section are similar to what would find in an intro to physics class. Brush up on your knowledge of basic physics and how it relates to velocity, volume, and pressure as well as the mechanics of simple machines when it comes to gears, electricity, and weight distribution.

Section 4: ANIT (Aviation and Nautical Information Test): You guessed it! On this section of the ASTB you’re going to need to know some nautical terminology, a little bit of aviation history as well as some principles of aviation like aerodynamic principles, basic aircraft components, and flight rules

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57033076

Section 5: NATFI (Naval Aviation Trait Facet Inventory): You sort of get off easy here as there’s no real way to prepare for this section. It’s a personality inventory that, in the end, will gauge ones suitability for a career in aviation based on their personal characteristics.

Section 6: PBM (Performance Based Measures Battery): Depending on your tastes this might be the most ‘fun’ part of the ASTB. You basically get to do a flight simulation. You’ll be given a flight mock-up flight console with a throttle and joystick along with a headset. You’ll also get a map that you’ll need to study before guiding an airplane around on a screen. For a more detailed of explanation of this section check out our full-length article of the different sections of the ASTB called ASTB Test Layout.

Section 7: BI-RV (Biographical Inventory with Response Validation): This is the part of the ASTB that you can complete from any computer with an internet connection. It is recommended that you complete this section prior to writing the rest of the ASTB. All it is, is a questionnaire about your previous experiences and successes or achievements with aviation. Like section 5 you really can’t prepare for this section – just answer honestly as there aren’t any real right or wrong responses.

IOW, bitch you should have prepared lel. Don't worry about it, but do study a little about basic history, math, and what you'd find in a toolbox.

dump a box of nails or bolts on top of and around the area of your cache

they will likely sift around and determine that their metal detector is pinging from all the little worthless pieces of metal and will move on

>Ok, just sell it to the Indians and Chinese even more at a large discount and take 60 to 70 percent of the profits now.
It's worse than that, actually. The fields supplying Europe are completely disconnected from the ones supplying China, and it would take western tech to get them connected. How do we know? Because the eastern fields - the ones supplying China - have been operated by western companies who've now pulled out, and if the random explosions throughout Russia that we keep hearing about are not Ukrainian sabotage it's gotta be incompetent Russian engineers who have no idea how to keep all this shit running.

Which means that the Russians can really only use Novorossiysk to ship their shit per ship. Well, ever since the price cap the Russians weren't able to indemnify their ships, and indemnification is required in case your ship has an accident in the Suez canal and blocks trade for everyone else. That has further caused consumption levels to drop.

Why is that important? Because the Russian oil wells are located in the permafrost, as in, frozen ground. The only reason the oil doesn't freeze there is because it's flowing into their pipe system, but if the consumption drops the oil starts backing up all the way to the well head, and then the oil stalls and freezes over and the well has to be redrilled. We know this because this has happened before, in 1991, when the USSR fell apart and oil consumption dropped to the bottom, and it took Russia 30 years and western tech to get back to the levels of production of 1991.

tl; dr: Russia is going to drop off the market unless they just open their pipes and let their oil overflow into some Siberian valley.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57033470
>It was an Army sergeant, and he would talk about weapons, their history, and effectiveness on the battlefield. Then he'd demonstrate them on the range.
It's probably one of R. Lee Ermey's old shows, he was a Marine. His most famous one in the late VHS era was Mail Call.
https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0337552/
You could be thinking of a couple different history channel shows, but I'm guessing this is what you meant. Ermey gets in a letter, reads it, explains the history of the weapon, and then murders the fuck out of watermelons.

>>57033508
Pusher prop configs are very fuel-efficient at low speeds. They're also unstable when you push them, and need large control surfaces or aggressive management. Good for slow, loitering designs with a completely disposable pilot willing to make constant micro-adjustments. Or a complete maniac. Tractor props are much more efficient and controllable at high speeds, which you absolutely need to survive in air-to-air combat.
Also, the safest way to land an aircraft is coming in near stall speed with the tail down. Coming in dragging ass with your slats down lets you "cheat" aerodynamics a little and get a much larger effective wing area. This lets you "dust off" if something goes wrong, while letting you hit the ground at the lowest speed possible. I'll give you a moment to consider why that might be a bad idea in a pusher prop. You'll notice that most of them have extremely long landing gear. That's practical in a design that doesn't have to take the extra load of a heavy, extremely valuable human being in the cockpit. A lightweight drone that already has a very low stall speed can afford to come in on a flatter trajectory. A faster aircraft will always have to have a higher minimum speed to not rip itself apart at top speed.

Pusher-prop fighters were basically abandoned as a concept in the 1930s, and by the time flight control systems and materials caught up enough to make them practical they were obsoleted by jets.

Sup /k/ I made a thread a while back about giving some love to my black powder rifle that I hadn't really shot in like 14 years. In it I mentioned I wanted to try hunting next season with it, i wanted to try and find an optic mount for it so I could use a nice 2x or something.
The only mounts I found were really cheap "universal" mounts that I would need to drill into and mount on the barrel which I am a tad Leary about doing. That got me thinking about maybe a custom 3d printed PLA mount of my own design.
That's when I borrowed an M1A mount for the purpose of banging it and my gun together like Im trying to get a stuffed dinosaur to kiss a Barbie doll and pull some inspiration from it.
Lo and behind this mounts bottom hole fits perfectly over where the lag bolt that holds The hammer assembly on gos. A slightly longer bolt and an oversized nut as a washer later and I have a very successful mock up IMO.
When I buy one of my own that I'm not borrowing I plan on grinding out the back a bit to conform to the guns shape a bit better, drill 2-4 more holes around the current mounting hole, add in some brass inserts with some glue, some proper sized machine bolts and blue locktite should do it.

What do you think? Will it hold zero? I'm fairly certain it will with the added mount holes and locktite but I AM going to be mounting it to the wood furniture.

Okay, to me if I'm going to carry a rifle then I want rifle power. Subsonic is PCC territory. I would jut get a PCC. Also, the sight in drastically changes. You can't just switch back and forth. You have to go through a zero'ing process. Therefore, I choose to stick with supers. So, why would I go with .300blk?
All of the .300blk powder is burnt up in the first 10 inches of barrel or at least that's what I've been told. Therefore every extension of barrel past that is an equal amount less pressure. Double the barrel length to 20, you double the volume, you cut the pressure in half. By this logic a 16" .300blk barrel has 10/16th the muzzle pressure of a 10" barrel, or almost 40% less. All of that pressure goes into expanding the suppressor. cont...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56987860
cont...

You have the muzzle blast heat but also the mechanical heat, like how hitting a nail with a hammer makes it hotter. Because the 16" .300blk has like 40% less blast, there's a lot less heat. There's also less pressure to suppress. So its' cooler and quieter by a significant margin. In addition you get a very complete powder burn and the suppressor stays cleaner. All of this is luxury that I enjoy while getting 2,400fps out of a 120gr projectile that says above the 2,000fps line out to almost 200 yards. Beyond 200 yards, a 5.56 would be better.

The problem with this is that you have a lot more muzzle mass to swing around. A bullpup would be ideal to help with this. So, a 16" .300blk bullpup would probably be my ideal rifle. The problem is I have not found one with a good trigger. Maybe the mdrx has a good trigger. I wouldn't know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56987958
>Aren't solenoid fired guns """"machine guns""" in the ATF's mind?
No, not inherently, but the ATF would check any electronic firing gun by the somewhat fuzzy standards of "ease of conversion" etc so right now it's untested as to how far it can go. There are 100% solutions that could satisfy it and stand up in court, from formally verified hard burned in ROM-based systems to electromechanical stuff like having the solenoid run off a carefully sized capacitor that is only physically large enough for a single activation and has a forced minimum recharge time before it can be used again, thus making it physically impossible to fire rapidly. There are ways to tie in trigger pull to activation that would be at least as hard to bypass as drilling a naughty hole and such. Remember manufacturers don't need perfection, they just need to show that it's as hard or harder than now.

There are lazy naive implementations though that would definitely count as machine guns, since the definition is basically anything where a single human action can translate into multiple rounds firing. But for now the tech just isn't ready yet in terms of reliability, cost and all the other bits that need to get polished. They'll be able to meet ATF standards (under court review) for semi-auto when they want to.

I think drone gun stuff is going to be more disruptive in that it's harder for the ATF to stop. An electronically fired rifle is still a rifle, a full gun item made by FFLs, they've got a framework for that. People jury rigging up setups to aim guns and pull triggers with motors is too multiple use if it catches on. They could tack it on as an extra crime I guess but that's going to be wild for security.

This is fundamentally incorrect. >Can someone make a can that isn't technically a suppressor?
Unfortunately no. Unlike with a lot of other aspects of the NFA/GCA (including AP ammo incidentally), Congress actually got that one ""right"" for whatever reason with an ultra broad functional definition that covers fucking anything. Law:
>The term “Firearm Silencer” or “Firearm Muffler” means any device for silencing, muffling, or diminishing the report of a portable firearm, including any combination of parts, designed or redesigned, and intended for the use in assembling or fabricating a firearm silencer or firearm muffler, any part intended only for use in such assembly or fabrication.
It's so stupid fucking shitty broad that ATF has been able to claim that even stuff like neoprene circles counts which has made wipe-based suppressors an extra stupid pita for zero value. It'd even cover stuff that didn't exist even in their imaginations, like if someone came up with active wave canceling system somehow. So yeah on that front cans get pretty fucked, though on the other hand they're also the only NFA items that you don't need to file forms to transport between states.
>What's the stabilizing brace of suppressors?
Nothing. I guess maybe if you really want to squint a blast can, which can mildly reduce sound at the shooter's ear in exchange for directing it all forward and making anyone in the vicinity hate you. But in this context nothing, a blast can creates zero back pressure so if the gun was designed with a certain amount in mind to cycle correctly then only a suppressor will do.

>>57010914
I assume they ended up having to give that up while making general improvements, including ease of manufacturing. MDR was amazing if you got a good one, friend got an early one and it has run like a dream through almost 10k rounds now. But at the same time tons and tons of people had major issues and a big one was in the challenges they had reliably manufacturing the forward eject stuff and maintaining QC, because if it was much out of spec it was a real problem. Having it come out entirely by default for swapping but also replacement/inspection probably helped. They only really started to finally modernize their QC/QA and CS etc like last summer, made the classic startup mistake of kinda ignoring their backend until things got pretty bad. Also they probably got a bit ahead of what they and their subcontractors/partners could do that early.

I mean, shit, at a much smaller scale I've been guilty of that. CAD is amazing but also makes it very easy to design and spec out stuff that is completely unrealistic for almost anyone in existence to actually manufacture with consistency. Especially a lot of the earlier stuff would cheerfully let do sub millimeter precision. Part of the wisdom of experience is knowing the difference between something the computer will show working and something you can make tens of thousands of with 99% in spec without breaking the bank.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57010215
Nitride processes are great, they’re especially good for making accurate and corrosion proof barrels cheaply.
If we’re talking about longevity in barrels there are 4 factors that determine your barrel life, barrel material, firing schedule, lining/treatment and method of manufacture.
Most quality barrel makers use machine gun steel like 4140 and 4150, the longest lasting barrels are made with a hammer forging process that work hardens the bore, button rifling doesn’t do this and is less durable as a result, chrome lining is more durable and heat resistant than melonite but costs more and may be less accurate, and how you use your barrel will make a huge difference. Nitride is not adequate for high firing schedules.

Personally I don’t mind nitride if it’s in weapons where it makes sense, low firing schedules, precision guns and budget firearms.
Steyr, SIG are the two worst when it comes to selling you a nitride barrel at chrome cold hammer forged prices. Don’t overpay for a budget barrel if you can help it.

Mildly irritated by this though for purely selfish reasons, barely have shot the thing and already feels like I would have been better off buying one right now not last year.

So it goes though, and they did put on the new charging handles and pay for shipping. Better the thing keep getting improved over time then not at all.
>308 mdrxs have reportedly erratic accuracy for whatever reason
According to the big serious characterization report, for coof guns (2021 up until like August or September last year?) they hadn't been using the correct thread locker (using loctite blue/242, not red/263) or properly torquing on barrel locking block screws. That could ultimately lead to some barrel whip. They can be cleaned/loctited/re-torqued (40 in-lbf). Not a design flaw just a really dumb little manufacturing fuckup that could then make things erratic. The sort of stupid unnecessary shit that they need to get a grip on since any gun it affected would look bad for no good reason, nobody would reasonably expect that to be an issue if they didn't know. Like, come the fuck on DT, design flaws happen, but it's another thing to have a good design and then fuck it up because someone gave assemblers the wrong fucking loctite.

>f the current AIM9 is so sensitive that it can pick up heat from a freaking balloon and its relatively cool payload, it'd be pretty useless in a dogfight
Nigger, you should stay at school.
AIM-9 is passive IR guided, and at that height there's fucking cold with very litle moisture in the air, so IR propagation is much better than at low altitudes. This is making a Sidewinder perfect tool for the job.
Secondly, the baloon itself will be like a fucking flare for IR sensor, more so for modern FPA that 9X is using. This will be because:
A) exteral surface of the blip must be covered in reflective shit to prevent overheating from the sun and unwanted expansion of the lifting gas and therefore will be sticking out against the cold atmospheric background like a pedo-necrophile dick in child orphanage mortuary(*)
or
B) it will be insulated for the same reason and in this case it will heat up and will be sticking out against the cold atmospheric background like... etc, etc.

If this fails (**), the shit hanging below blip had a fuckhuge solar panles attached to it, and these, for strictly technical reason, must be BLACK. If you can't comprehend what is a connection between black surface, sun and infrared radiation you are probably too retarded to understood any word from this post anyway, so in such case - fuck off and kys.

TL;DR - AIM-9 was the only sensible option, it superb performance against this type of target mean that it's perfect missile for engaging other, less demanding targets, and you are a fucking clueless melanin-enriched dingus.

(*) - judging by the pictures it's probably not the case, therefore refer to case B.
{**) - again, judging by the pictures and videos, AIM-9 was perfectly able to get a lock on the blip itself and fucked it up admirably, so it wasn't necessary to use that plan B

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57030229
>Does a balloon have a heat signature?
AIM-9X Block IIs have datalinks and extremely sensitive thermal imagers that are closer to FLIR cameras than the old AIM-9Bs or Ds used in Vietnam. Considering the outside of the satellite bus (which is basically what the sensor part of the balloon is) is connected to the inside, which would have to operate above -30C, there's more than enough heat there for the AIM-9 to lock onto.

I think commercial FLIR imagery auto adjusting for the range of heat in a scene confuses laymen as to how sensitive these systems actually are. They see a person on a cool backdrop with a perceived "small" dynamic range because of the color grading (so 30-40C max) and don't realize that the same system is probably capable of discerning a 400C object down to 0.1C resolution against a 0C backdrop.

I'm not an expert so I could be entirely off the mark here, but...

AIM-9s use IR guidance which basically locks onto the bright spot in an image. Usually the exhaust of a jet, the heat of an engine, or flares launched as countermeasures. This causes people to think they're purely heat-seeking, but they really look for contrast in the image from their camera, for example a white balloon against an empty sky. See >>57030284

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57024669
Its a legacy of the soviet union's competing design bureaus but they both had different purposes. The T-72 is a product of the T-34 myth of numbers=quality, but in its intended use and time it wasnt that bad, it was a mass combined warfare tank designed to rush the Fulda Gap and meet the soviet need for tank numbers, not the durable high value multi-role infantry support/skirmish/sniper tank of modern warfare. Russia is poor but wants a large military. They physically have a lot of T-72s, so they want to use them. More importantly they also physically already have the factory for T-72s (UVZ). Most of T-80 production was in what is now Ukraine, Russia had some production but much less, in fact Russia only has the capacity to upgrade T-80 B models, T-80U models from storage cant be upgraded because those needs parts exclusively from ukraine. So its more feasible for them to just continue with the T-72 line (T-90).
T-80s are much better but are more logistically intensive due to the gas turbine engine, and Russia doesnt actually have the factory facilities in place for them like it does for the T-72 line. It prioritises T-80s for the 4th Guard Tank Division, and for its arctic brigades+brigades attached to naval commands which might operate in arctic or cold conditions, as the gas turbine works much better in the cold than the T-72s engine does. Russia can upgrade 25 T-80 BVMs a year, but it can upgrade 500 T-72B3Ms a year and produce some 100-185 T-90s a year.

Not that continuing to upgrade T-72s is neccessarily a good idea, most of them were put into storage heavily used, and then badly maintained throughout the 90s, often not even stored but just left in a field. Now they cost almost as much to recondition and upgrade to B3M standard from storage, as building a new T-90, which is contrary to the point of a T-72 being a cheap+cost effective tank.

Nobody is panicking in NATO, the regional power is getting fucked back to the 90s by NATO SIGNINT/ELINT and AA systems, Russia cant establish useable air superiority over Ukraine, Russia still hasnt organsied its logistics properly, so it lost a large number of its tanks, and so its forced into trench warfare and artillery duels. Its in stalemate now.
Russia doesnt have the resources to take a shitty 2nd world country backed by NATO, much less actually take on NATO itself.
It needs to maintain three different fleets for three different seas/oceans.
It needs to maintain a large enough airforce to cover two different continents.
It needs a large enough army to defend the largest border in the world.
Their military needs are huge. Modern technology is expensive and requires a constant cycle of development, as well as institutional investment, research and knowledge, which requires a strong economy and large population. Russia has none of these things.
Going into the late 2020s+2030s they need to look at army, navy, airforce, and choose two to prioritise. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57023967
5.7 doesn't have an appropriate diameter to expand reliably, hollowpoints only expand 1/5th of the time and the one that does still has very poor expansion. You're entirely relying on fragmentation or tumbling to occur to get a bigger wound channel than a .22 hole. If you know your ballistic shit, you know all the planets have to align for tumbling and fragmentation to happen. I'd say those are unreliable wounding mechanisms too. Ultimately, 5.7 lacks the mass to penetrate light barriers like windshields and car doors without excessive deflection. It will never be adopted as a police duty round for those reasons.

.40 did what it was designed to do, which was be 10-15% better than 9mm. It still is, because modern powder advancements improved .40 loads too. 9mm now consistently makes the minimum penetration requirements, but the one thing .40 still has a leg up on is light barrier penetration. It will go through something like a windshield or car door with less deflection than 9mm. The police agencies may not have made the right decision to drop it, but I wouldn't invest in it because it won't be a common round in the future. Just get a 10mm if you want something that blows 9 the fuck out of the water. There's a lot of badass versatile loads you can get in 10mm that you can't get with boring cope rounds like .40 or .357. 9mm is just a good all around, very common round. A must have but not a beast by any means, leaves a little to be desired.

I wouldn't trust it as an all around handgun calibers until I see testing on that. I haven't, I'm just assuming. That's where these light .20 cal rounds don't perform well. Even rifle .20 caps like 5.56 can deflect from twigs being in the bullet path, and they struggle with any sort of barrier penetration at range. There are verified reports from the sandbox that it bounces off car windshields in firefights at extended ranges.

This would be a good thing to suggest a reviewer to test out. It's a promising round but it's a tiny little baby, I don't anticipate it doing well. Ammo manufacturers also need to revisit 5.7 loadings because they don't have adequate ballistics gel penetration depth. They typically stop just short of 12"

My favorite gun for a while is Big Bertha (the Marlin 1895 trapper in the pic) With her, I tagged four bucks, and a handsome looking Moose while I was up north. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57029313
Owing to your picture of big hunting revolvers there, it's because it's a LOT cheaper to make a high powered repeating handgun such as a revolver, especially on existing tooling and going on existing designs, than it is to develop and produce a proper automatic pistol.

The Desert Eagle is designed around mostly rimmed revolver cartridges, but it's a picky bitch when it comes to what kind of ammo it likes, and it only tolerates perfect shooting stance. The Coonan and Grizzly are probably the most practical Magnum autos ever, but they're expensive, and the latter hasn't been in production for many years, tragically, we're also up into Coonan's second revival.
The Wildey has certain adaptability, but is also expensive, and is built around rimless Magnum handgun cartridges which aren't widely available. The AMC Auto Mag has had promise, but it has been handled awfully for most of its history, and there's a lot of problems, maybe the revamped ones have this solved and it'll have a better shot, we'll see, but just the same it calls for less common rimless ammunition. The AMT Automag (which is different) is vaguely like the Grizzly if it was retarded.

Beyond that, revolvers have this appeal to reliability, with how they don't depend on the power of your cartridge to cycle (outside of rare exceptions), and that they're very simple to handle. We can argue just how truthful or relevant this reliability part really is, particularly with how even cheap ammo these days is lightyears ahead of cheap ammo from over a century ago, or how revolver lockworks have all these big openings for hypothetical dirt to get in.
Most people don't live in a WW1 trench though, and they don't shoot mysterious unlabeled ammo they found under the fridge when they moved in, so typically their revolvers don't struggle to function. The modest (centerfire) snubbie revolver has a record of being adequate for defense 999 times out of 1000, so it's not going away any time soon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: People should understand that while there are valid cons to .40 vis-à-vis the alternatives, some criticisms are more subjective. I often hear that it's "too snappy," but I don't agree. The best target shooting I've ever done with a handgun was with a police trade in Gen 3 Glock 22. If a gun appeals to and works for you, don't dismiss it on account of a two-round difference in magazine capacity or popular opinions about snappiness and obsolescence. The heyday of .40 S&W may be past, but it wasn't that long ago. It's no less effective now than it was a few years ago when nearly every cop in America was carrying one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57034891
Snappiness, ie muzzle flip, only becomes apparent when you shoot rapidly (minimum 3-4 shots per second) and is an issue because it increases the time it takes your sights to return to the target. Cops stopped using 40 and 357 sig when they realized that slow fire has no bearing on actual tactical use of handguns.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57034316
The amount of shot and the powder charge behind it are more important to pay attention to. 1 1/2 oz. of shot traveling at 1200 feet per second is going to ruin your day. Doesn't matter if it's #4 buck or 00 buck. It WILL matter if you get into birdshot at a distance over ~20 feet. So, stay away from birdshot. BB & BBB are the smallest you'd want to go, but they are devastating at typical home defense close range 25 yards and under (usually about 8-10 yards).

Notice that #1 buck is .30 cal. I always liked that as my go-to, but it's tough to find anymore. Single-0 and #1 used to be fairly common.

You want to look for 3" or even 3 1/2" shells so you can fit a little more weight/a few more pellets plus a more authoritative powder charge, so you might get more like 1 3/4 oz. moving at ~1400 fps. Steel will weigh less, but travel faster. If you can find #4 buck in a 3" shell, you might be looking at ~1 5/8 oz. 27 steel pellets moving ~1450 or 1500 fps. It will fuck your day up.

What is a bit easier to find is >>57034439 waterfowl goose loads in 3" or 3 1/2" shells pushing steel BB shot between 1500 to 1600 fps depending on powder, etc. At close range it will still penetrate gypsum board sheetrock walls, but be far less dangerous to anything on the other side. At about 8-10 yards it will make a hole in your target about twice the size of 12 gauge, especially if you're using a modified choke. At ~20 yards that hole will be more like fist-sized. A cylinder or improved cylinder choke will spread slightly, but not much at those ranges. If you're shooting at 30 or more yards you should be using something else, like a slug or a handgun.

tl;dr - #4 or 00 doesn't matter at home defense ranges, the weight & velocity is more important. If penetrating walls is an issue, use smaller shot (#4 buck or BB), otherwise 00 is fine. Too. If you find a few boxes of #1 buck, put them in your stockpile; it's a good option to have. Also some slugs.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57018968
Yeah, there are tons of lighter than air drones coming out.

They aren't airships though. They tend to be either very high altitude surveillance/comms/EW platforms or small low altitude drones.

The large ones can do all sorts of neat stuff that LEO satalites can do but sometimes better. They can be used down to spotting for artillery or MLRS, although satalites have recently done this too. They can also spot for interceptors and drop munitions.

Small lighter than air drones have a huge advantage in cost and persistence. They are obviously easier to detect than heavier than air, but being quite small they aren't super easy to find. Nor would it be practical to waste many conventional AA assets on them, especially when decoys are incredibly cheap and can be dispersed as noise.

The big advantage is that they can stay up forever, and have sensors looking out. Each tank or IFV could conceivably have one up at all times using cameras and other sensors, feeding the data back for analysis for constant threat detection and target spotting. You're not going to use them as designators generally, but to spot targets for normal drones to designate or to spot an ATGM launch or incoming shell for interception. Again, decoys are super cheap so they don't necessarily call out their vehicle either.

Other use is as relays for comms. Helps for laser/other open space comms that are harder to jam or locate. Vehicles can transmit to these for radio rebroadcast to reduce noise and they can carry back hard to jam targeting data from spotter drones. They also don't fall out of the sky if the electronics stop working. For use with other assets obviously.

Some new larger ones can stay up indefinitely with solar, which with autonomous navigation and AI threat recognition to sort data makes for an ideal patrol sensor.

>>57019017
Still hard to find small UAVs, especially in a sea of noise.

High altitude ones are at 70,000-120,000 feet. Much AA can't hit them.

As PGMs keep getting cheaper and proliferating, autonomous artillery systems become the norm, and integrated spotter drones that can autonomously find and designate targets, even moving ones, get common, lighter than air UAVs will become essential and common. Integrated battle space fire mission queues, where swarms of autonomous spotters with full EM sensors feed in targets in, and then AI recognition packages can select appropriate munitions and the best asset to carry out the mission, will make fire missions incredibly rapid. Autonomous mortars on IFVs and new smart optics will eventually mean a fire mission is a button press away for riflemen. When guns can aim themselves (and eventually be loaded by munitions delivered by UGVs) humans just need to focus on higher level decision-making m, approving fires, and troubleshooting. Shit will come in fast and furious.

Active protection on every vehicle is part of the solution, but you need multiple overlapping levels of defense. That is where swarms of persistent, cheap lighter than air assets come in, for sensors and comms.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57018968
>Small balloons
Do whatever other drones can do but stay up longer and are cheaper at the cost of reduced speed and higher visibility. The persistence makes them far better picks for communications relays for laser, etc. Mix of both is wanted.

>Larger airship drones operating at the same altitudes fighter aircraft and commercial aircraft do.

Potentially limitless range and duration. Much slower and easier to spot. Good for comms relays if defended and held back. Can see a long ways. Best for patrolling areas with sensors. If it gets shot down, you know something is there. If it doesn't get shot down, a radar system with multiple ground receivers and floating drones will find stealth aircraft much better.

>Super high altitude.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57025930
>Yeah but batteries will always be bulky
Not necessarily. For example, the lithium battery pack needed to get 20 miles out of a ebike is the size of a 1L soda and weigh ~10lb, 10lb of battery can haul 200 lb human for 20 miles on a charge and you can extend that range to double or triple if you use pedal a bit. With a lithium battery and an optimized exe-skeleton, you should be able to use exo-skeleton for an hour or so of running. You're not offloading the entire running to battery powered exo skeleton like you're with an ebike. You're only gaining about 10-20% efficiency in running as it augments your muscles a bit. But that augmenting means you're able to do more things for longer without being tired.

If you can reload an artillery shell for 20% longer vs your opponent, or 20% faster or can carry 20% more load, then thats a huge boost.

>>57025291
Battery/capacitor technologies are the only storage method that have room for improvement and it's in the order of 20x more at minimum.
Combustion engines waste 70% of the energy of fuel as heat, even if we invented a world changing converter to get 100% it would only be a x2 increase in range.

We can't predict such game-changing battery improvement, but at least the laws of physics don't argue against it.
Generating all that electric energy and getting it to battery will remain a problem but the energy efficiency of electric motor (>90%) mean we could save a LOT of fuel by improving dedicated field generators.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57026125
If you want to know what the actual problem is...
This is not a finished product. This is an intermediate stage in the barrel manufacture.
>first you make a rod
>then you drill the rod
>then you polish and reduce the barel compensating for errors made in step 2, because there will be errors in step 2
>then you do the final shaping to make it fit the gun
What you're looking at here is someone who stopped at Step 2 and then shipped this to the frontlines as a replacement barrel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The terminator's original intent for its cannon was to have a single 30mm cannon with an automated dual feed mechanism. This would enable the crew to effortlessly switch between specialized ammo types so they could change from engaging armor and hardened defenses to infantry in light cover effortlessly on the fly. It was supposed to replace infantry for protecting tanks in restrictive urban environments while supporting armored assaults directly in open combat.

In reality, this dual feed auto loader mechanism was a bit beyond orkish pockets to afford and orkish engineers to make reliable, so they went with a double cannon setup. The theory was they could load one cannon with anti-infantry ammo types and the other with anti-armor ammo types. Except managing two different ammo reserves under the stress of combat proved too complicated for orkish gunner's skill levels.

So now they just use it in a default setting with the same ammo type in both guns. mo dakka, spray and pray style as is orkish custom.

Also, remote control turrets as a survivability feature is a meme. They just end up limiting crew situational awareness, which limits it's ability to perform in dense urban environments. The entire terminator concept was created to be a sort of "armored vehicle support vehicle" instead of an IFV because in order for proper combined arms assault you need well equipped, well trained, well disciplined, well motivated infantry to support the armored assault. Again, a bit beyond orkish training, funding, and doctrinal abilities. Atleast on any scale that matters. Furthermore, for an armored assault to work you need infantry to hold the ground that was taken as well as provide heavy vehicles with the situational awareness they desperately lack. The terminator can't do this any better than any other armored vehicle can.

Tl;dr. The terminator exists because russia can't figure out how to properly support tanks with infantry, and doesn't even do that right either.

>>57034227
The theory behind the terminator is a perfect example of how what looks good on paper doesn't translate to battlefield conditions without extensive real world testing.

In chechnya russia had a few issues. The first was that traditional armored vehicle's guns can't depress or elevate enough to street fight determined defenders dug into basements or on top of tall buildings. The second was that in order for infantry to support armor, they need to be very skilled and equipped and have high morale. Russia's don't outside of a few units.

So, why not make a vehicle designed to support armor? Lets give its guns the range of motion to aim in close quarters. Hey, who is the first to die from anti-armor attacks? The gunner! Make the turret remote controlled! Oh, also it needs to support tanks in open warfare too, so slap ATGMs on there. 4 of them! Thats two more than the bradley (that kicks our vehicles asses) so its now twice as good! Okay, so our dual feed system is shit and managing two seperate ammo stores is too complicated, we still have twice the guns and twice the missiles right?

Actually, you have a vehicle that supplies even less situational awareness, so its still vulnerable in close quarters. It has twice the weapons systems so there's twice as hard to maintain as well as being twice as likely to break as well as being twice as expensive. (srsly, when are you going to get the chance to fire 4 ATGMs in one modern battle without being detected, targeted, and destroyed first?)

In short, it still suffers all the pitfalls of the old vehicles while costing way more and being even easier to break and more difficult to repair.

BUT IT SURE LOOKS BADASS ON PARADE IN THE RED SQUARE SO FUCK IT, RUSH THEM INTO PRODUCTION!

Russian military R&D everybody.

>>57034482
Combined arms requires specialized, motivated, professional troops with expensive equipment they are expertly trained on, as well as a reliable comms systems and an extensive command and control element. These aren't non-existent in the russian war machine, but they are very limited.

Right now russian assaults in regions like bakhmut follow this pattern:
1: Russian unit is given a series of checkpoints along a general line of advance to secure
2: Arty does a preliminary bombardment (without spotting or recon)
3: Russian infantry advance on their predetermined, inflexible checklist
4: They fight if engaged
5: Only critically wounded are allowed to retreat
6: Russian arty opens up on anything engaging
7: By this time ukrainians who know the drill use this gap to retreat a short distance and call their own arty to screen them
8: Russia declares victory over 650 ukrainian ultra-commando generals killed, great victory!
9: They are now occupying former ukrainian positions, thus easily targeted
10: Ukraine pounds them with arty, the the "650 ultra-commando generals" (25 national guards men) retake their old position, then relocate and dig in again.
11: ??????
12: UKRAINE DE-NAZIFIED, GREAT SUCCESS
13: Do it again tomorrow

So yeah. Russians can't into combined arms. They have a few elite unuts who can, but the bulk of russian forces lack the initiative, comms, command and control, and just basic general skill level to do so even if their generals wanted to.

Two days ago, I lost a duck to turtles (yes, TURTLES!!) in my pond. Last night, I found a 6 foot snake in the hen house, which I dispatched with an axe (although not before it struck at me twice).

So, I'm finally ready to buy a varmint gun like my wife has been begging me for the past 5 years.

I'm an ex-Marine weapons platoon sgt who fired high expert with his M-14 or M-16 at the rifle range four years straight, so I know about guns and how to handle them. However, I've never owned a weapon as a civilian so know little about civilian weaponry, and I doubt they will let me rustle up and M-14.

So here I am for advice. What's a good all-purpose rifle for varmints? I need one for snakes, coons, possums, and turtles, maybe a coyote. We have bobcats around here but they don't tend to come up close enough to the house to worry about.

I don't need one for home protection, since that is not something I tend to worry about. Just a good, all 'round varmint killer.

Types of guns would be good (22, shotgun, etc), but brands would be nice to know about as well. I figure some may be more reliable or accurate than others.

So, what's your choice of weapons when it comes to killing critters?
