posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57031776
NTA, but Virginia-class boats only have 12x VLS cells for tomahawks. Whereas the UK's Astute-class boats have UP to 36 tomahawks, though realistically they split their loadout between tomahawks and torpedos likely favouring torpedos since the UK isn't about using their SSNs for land attack. I believe most Astute-class boats would have 12 tomahawks and 24 torpedos to match a standard US Virginia-class boat armament. But theoretically, an Astute-class boat on a specific land-attack mission could be loaded up with purely tomahawks and have more than a Virginia-class boat.

The Block V Virginia-class adds the VPM which increases the VLS cells to 40 (28 VLS cells in the VPM + 12 in the standard VLS cells) plus the standard torpedo loadout on top of that, which takes it beyond the Astute-class in land-attack potential. But as of right now, no Block V boats are in service (2027?) yet.


tldr; he's technically correct but also kinda wrong based on actual deployment use.

Recently tuned a load for my .308 and was disappointed that the smallest groups I could print were ~1.2 MoA for 5 shots.

Decided to clean copper fouling for the first time ever (barrel has ~400 rounds through it), changing over from bore seasoning and copper equilibrium approach.

Now the rifle prints .6 MoA 5 shot groups from a bipod with all else held equal.

Where do you all line up on bore seasoning, copper cleaning, and break in procedures?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What do you all find is the influence of primers on precision?

I did an experiment with 10 different kinds and found the best (CCI 200) produced sub MoA groups, most other types (including specifically marketed "bench rest" primers) produced ~1.2 MoA groups and the worst (CCI 100 "NATO spec") produced groups in excess of 1.5 MoA

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56966913
what was your test protocol? for 5.56 i haven't noticed much difference but I guess i could try

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56966924
Test protocol was to load 10 rounds with each type of primer with everything else about the load held equal - obviously components but on top of that bullet seating depth (+/- .003"), all cases full length resized and controlled for work hardening by making sure they were shot the same number of times through the same chamber prior to test.

Shot one five shot group at "rapid fire" cadence (~10 secs between shots) and used an IR thermometer to temp check the barrel, waiting until it cooled to the same temp before firing the next group.

Cleaned the barrel after firing through the loads once, then shot through them in the opposite order to control for imprecision due to fouling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm a reservist in my country's infantry, and a pretty accomplished shooter and instructor. over the last years I've been fortunate enough to instruct, shoot, and improve long-range direct and indirect machine gunnery: firing 7.62 out to almost 3km, with the goal of harassing large stretches of ground.

Two years before this, I started shooting long range with 7.62, learning to push it accurately out to 1000 meters, and got pretty into long range firing drills and solutions. I owe where I am now to what I've learned in the long range world

What I'm working on now is how to use the support weapon sight to measure precise angles, and generating accurate "rifleman's rule" formulas that'll allow us to better fire in high angle environments in milliradians.

We don't tamper with the issued ammo, the 1:12.5, 24" barrel likely wouldn't stabilize a 175gr, maybe a 168gr.

So we use 149gr ball and 142gr trace 4B1T, we've still been able to land 2200m point hits, and 3200m area hits on targets in defilade. But at those distances, your bullets have the energy of a .22lr, so it's really harassment, and me make up for the lack of precision and energy with sheer volume: 20-50 round bursts, for 200-1000 rounds on targets depending on type.

Whats a good bipod for a rifle? I went with basic level magpul because some of these other atlas or harris start really ramping up in prices. I didnt want to spend hundreds on something I wasnt even sure was good or worth it. What benefits do the higher end bipods bring?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56984806
>What benefits do the higher end bipods bring?
they're not made out of plastic for one thing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56984806
I have a Magpul, I have an Atlas CAL. What you're paying for is certainty in lockup - with the Magpul I would be constantly trying to lock out cant and fight the bipod to dial out the last little bit of it. A useful technique shooting off a bipod is to position yourself so that as you pull the rifle into your shoulder, you then take up slack in the bipod legs by pre-loading it with a little bit of forward pressure coming from your hips - hard to articulate but it makes sense when you're in the prone. That little bit of preloading encourages the rifle to recoil straight backwards into the shoulder when you press the trigger. The CAL does so more securely than the Magpul.

I think the Magpul is a pretty good bipod; I think the CAL is quite a bit better. I think Harris bipods are products of a passed age and no longer relevant, but I get that people still like them.

Trijicon makes solid scopes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57007067
>>57007184
>>57010870
These guys are right. You still can make something effective but knowing where to make compromises is important.
Some things to note
>handloading will get you dramatically more performance on velocity spread, top velocity, finding a charge weight to get a bullet you want to shoot well, and offer greater access to even higher BC bullets
>most older clambering have slow twist rates in factory guns that aren't going to work for you if you want range. Google Berger Twist rate calculator and leave environment default at 0 feet then fill in your gun and bullet specs.
>300wm is long. So long that many guns at saami lengths have near no room to work with adjusting COAL so you're stuck with single feed, very low velocities, or lower BC bullets. If you're wanting to keep things simple I started pushing people toward 7rm just because it's easier to work with in this regard.
>thinner barrels string with heat earlier which sucks for shooting day but can be okay for hunting where you're not likely to pull the trigger may times
>try to keep the gun under 13lbs but ideally under 11lbs. If magnum get a muzzle brake so you can more comfortably shoot in more field positions. A quality tripod set up is a necessity to get above foliage lines and put your spotting scope on; it needs to be able to securely hold your gun.
>you're on the right path with the optic. Many of the nicer ones are very heavy and expensive.
>use a ballistic calculator that shows your distance velocity so you know what your expansion range is.

If you want to experiment, one route could be to do something like a savage tactical in 308 or creedmoor, swfa fixed 12x, magpul bipod, chronograph, range finder, wind speed meter, standard pressure chart, drop chart in 1-2k feet intervals, and eldm bullets would be a good start. Later, get into handloading for match and learn to bed on this gun with a bell and Carlson stock

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57012223
You're adjusting volume of an individual pour. The grain measurements you see are only ballpark correct and will be different for different powders.
Volume is always less accurate than actually weighing it but they can be very handy for the initial powder dump.
Ex
>need 50.6gr charge
>pour ~50gr at once from powder dump
>put on scale
>it's +/- 0.4gr
>use powder trickler while still on scale (slower but much more fine controllable changes) to get up to 50.6 grains

It makes it faster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57026731
>breaking ceramic plates
You need something a little harder than brass. You also need to maximize sectional density, and within reason minimize the diameter (frontal/contact surface area) so you can maximize the amount of energy for a given surface area. Tungsten carbide, which is a restricted material, would be much better than brass for a projectile meant to damage/penetrate armor plates, as it is much higher density, much harder, and capable of being more easily machined into a projectile or projectile core. Some anons here (who supposedly already got v&) were working on how to make cheap and consistent tungsten carbide cored .30cal ap and share a guide.
For shits and giggles you could create a spreadsheet that allows you to calculate the volume and mass of different diameter and length projectiles or projectile cores, to create some guidelines for any sort of experimentation you wanted to do, well before you go buying any material. You could, for example, take the dimensional limits of standard projectile of a given weight, and constrain your "cored" projectile to dimensions that fit within the existing projectile, while maximizing the sectional density and mass of the core, along with whatever filler material you fill the rest of the existing jacket with. With a standard projectile size and staying close to its original mass, you have limited the amount of load data you need to work on in order to reload such a projectile. But you've got something that should be capable of defeating a significantly tougher target.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57031822
>Secondly, the aim-9x has a very advanced seeker head that is beyond just heat seeking at this point.
This, the imaging IR seeker may as well be pulling secondary duty as a fire and forget contrasting image seeker package at the resolution and field of view they get out of that thing.
Pair that with the helmet sight integration where applicable as well.

>>57033752
It's a imaging infrared seeker, it doesn't just follow any random heat source, it follows the infrared image that matches the image it was initially locked on to in terms of contrast and a number of other image criteria being processed within the seekers field of view, including movement prediction.
So yes it is that sensitive, no it is less likely to be distracted by other heat sources, because that was specifically why imaging infrared seekers were designed in the first place.

AMRAAM would be a less likely candidate because of both a larger warhead being more likely to cause much more extensive damage to the payload, the fact that it would be most likely to target the payload rather than the balloon itself and limited targeting parameters other than "destroy first radar signature it detects in this direction after going active".

Also, looking at the video the missile burns out fairly quickly, while the AMRAAM would likely still be in its boost phase all the way to the target at that close range.
